entry.title: Cycle counter using AUoM has +/-'ve negated adjustment in PI Document
entry.content:
Hi all,

We currently have an concern where the Cycle counters are entering in a PAC UoM when initiating a cycle count via RF and the location they are counting has the current AUoM as EA.

I've been told this is standard and this causes the system to create a -/+'ve adjustment to write the stock on with the counted AUoM.

While most of the time this does negate the actual count variance and I've tried to explain that this is simply because the system is changing the AUoM, they want it to always to process the PI Document count as BUoM irrespective of what the cycle counter entered or Preferred UoM is. 

I've had a look through SPRO and been searching trying to find if there's a BAPi that would assist with this but not too much luck so thought I'd ask here just in case there is that I haven't found or in the long run, we'd need to get an ABAP developer in to 'fix' this. 

We want to avoid EA write-off + PAC write-on splits and post only BUoM for PI counts even if the counter entered PAC on RF without losing the correct base quantity reconciliation.

Looking for any standard config or official enhancement guidance to achieve this, otherwise, project-proven approaches are appreciated.

entry.title: SII tip for Spain #5: SII Adjustments for Canary Islands October 2025
entry.content:
The Canary Islands is an Spanish region which, due to certain particularities and specifications, such as its geographical location, the scarcity of natural resources or distance to the EU continent ( it is an outermost region of the European Union), has a different economic and fiscal regime from the rest of the Spanish territory.

This mainly means that while being part of the EU customs territory and having the same customs legislation, indirect taxation is different and there is a specific tax for this part of the EU customs territory. In the Canary Islands, for example, Value Added Tax (VAT) or certain Excise Taxes do not apply. Instead, the transport operations to the Canary Islands are subject to own tax such as the General Indirect Canary Tax (IGIC), the Tax on Petroleum Derived Fuels or the Tax on Imports and Deliveries of Goods in the Canary Islands (AIEM).

The Canary Islands Tax Agency published the Order of July 10, 2025 modifying Order of 11 October 2018, regulating the technical and legal specifications of the IGIC registry books  containing a set of changes in the Canary Islands SII format.  In the Annex of the given Order, the technical specifications are detailed.

The summary of the changes contained in the new Law are the following.

New Regimes

Regime (ClaveRegimenEspecialOTrascendencia) "08", currently for Transactions subject to VAT/IPSI is split into two:

  • In case of incoming invoices: 
    • Regime "08" (Transactions subject to VAT)
    • New Regime "18" (Transactions subject toIPSI)
  • In case of outgoing invoices:
    • Regime "08" (Transactions subject to VAT)
    • New Regime "20" (Transactions subject to IPSI)

Additionally,  new combinations of regime 18  (incoming invoices) are required:

 

New combinations of regime 20 (outgoing invoices) are also provided:

 

 

 

The new Regimes will be available in the SII customzing for incoming and for outgoing invoices. The SII will support the same combinations for of regimes 18 and 20 as they were supported for the original 08.

AIEM tax

New XML structure <OperacionSujetaAIEM> . In case the transaction is subject to AIEM (supplies made by companies, on a regular or occasional basis for commercial reasons, of manufactured personal movable property as included in annex IV of Law 24/2001,  and also the imports of the goods listed in the Annex IV):  

  • The AIEM amount shall be separated from the IGIC amount (<CuotaSoportada>)
  • The summary of the AIEM amount shall be reported in the new tag <CuotaAIEM> in the new XML structure.
  • The deductible amount in case of incoming invoices (<CuotaDeducible>) shall not include the AIEM amount
  • The total amount of the invoice (<ImporteTotal>) shall include also the AIEM amount in case this optional field is reported

 

Customers subject to AIEM are required to extend the Spanish tax procedure with their own AIEM transactions keys (for example, ZAI for AIEM input, o ZAO for AIEM output).

 

A new customizing activity in  SII will allow the use to define the new transaction keys for AIEM tax (SSCUI 107186, “Assign Settings for Accounting Key Tax Type”).

The Canary Islands SII process will check this customizing activity and populate the tags <CuotaAIEM> , <CuotaDeducible> and <ImporteTotal> (if required) .

 

Special taxes managed by the Canary Islands Tax Agency

New XML structure <OperacionSujetaIIEEgestCAC>. In case the transaction is subject to the special taxes managed  by the Canary Islands Tax Agency (such as Tobacco, Petroleum-based fuels and Wastes deposited in landfills for incineration and co-incineration), the new tags under this new structure must be populated:

  • <ClaveImpuestoEspecial>
  • <Exenta>
  • <RegimenSuspensivo>
  • <CuotaIIEECAC>

Customers with transactions subject to the these special taxes can use method SET_OUTPUT_DATA of BAdI EDOC_ADAPTOR to fill these fields

 

Timeline

We are currently working in finalizing the solution by October 2025. Please check the announcement "SII for Canary Islands 2025" in the Regulatory Change Manager for further details.

In case of additional questions, you can visit the SII help documentation in the following links:

  • Electronic Tax Register Books with SII in S/4HANA Public Cloud
  • Electronic Tax Register Books with SII in S/4HANA Private Cloud
  • Electronic Tax Register Books with SII in ERP

Other SII tips:

  • SII tip for Spain #4: Errors 1116, 1117 and 2011: Issues with the Identification service

entry.title: Re: Request to Guidance how to Activate File Upload Restr...
entry.content:
The Standard Deliveried DMS Document types shown in the configuration activity 'Define DMS Document Types' cannot be restricted through use of the Maintain Business Role app

 

In S/4HANA Public Cloud it is possible to create custom DMS Document types and use the Business Catalog SAP_PLM_BC_DIR_CUSTOM_PC  and restrict access to them 

 

Please refer to the resource Configuring the Business Catalog for Custom Document Types

entry.title: Re: ABAP test cockpit (ATC) recommendations for governance of clean core ABAP development
entry.content:
Hi  @OlgaDolinskaja 

We implemented 3565942 on our central ATC system and verified we had all the pre-requisite and dependent notes for the Central system by running the central Note Analyzer file in 3627152

When we tried to run a copy of ABAP_CLOUD_DEVELOPMENT_DEFAULT (With the new Clean core -> Usage of APIs check switched on) on a remote system, we encountered errors due to missing check classes. To resolve this we implemented 3568611 on the target system, once again verifying that we had installed the pre-requisite and dependent notes on our Target system using  the target Note Analyzer file in 3627152.

This resolved the issue, so we could now execute the ATC checks, however we are now getting a errors on some of the checks during the run, which seems to require 3454025, which we will implement shortly.

The question I have is that since the target transport 3568611 is only relevant for 754+, does this mean that after implementing 3627152 on our central ATC system, we can only run checks on 754+ target systems?

Reason for the question is that some of the systems we want to analyze are on 752 and based on what we're seeing after implementing 3568611, we cannot run ABAP_CLOUD_DEVELOPMENT_DEFAULT on 752 systems. A workaround could be to move the code to a 754 system, and run the checks there, but we would obviously prefer to avoid doing this if possible, hence reaching out to you!

Thanks

Doug

entry.title: 24 hour rest period in between change of shifts
entry.content:
Hi experts!

We have a requirement to trigger an alert if the employee clocks in after a shift change and there is less than 24 hours break between shifts.

This is related to the Rest Rule configuration. The difference is just that Rest Period should be 24 hours and should only trigger if there is a shift change

For example:

Monday - EE is working on a night shift sched of 22:00 - 07:00 (Next day)

Tuesday - Non working Day (07:00 - end of previous day shift)

Wednesday - EE is working on Day Shift - 7:00 - 16:00, but he clocks in earlier than 07:00 (e.g. 06:30)

So break is just 23hours 30mins - this should trigger an alert.

 

I followed KBA 3323455 - Rest Rule configuration sample.  However, it gets triggered on other days where there is less than 24 hour rest.  

Would you have any idea/solution on how I can filter it to trigger only when there was a shift change?

entry.title: Need Help with MB_MIGO_BADI Enhancement – Skip Shelf Life Check for PO Type ZNB7
entry.content:
Hello SAP Experts,

I need your advice on a MB_MIGO_BADI enhancement.

Requirement:
When the purchase order header field EKKO-BSART = 'ZNB7' and the movement type is 101, I want to skip the product (shelf life) date entry check during MIGO goods receipt.

I’ve implemented the BADI and tried to control this via the check_item and line_modify methods, but it’s not working — the system still prompts for the shelf life date.

Here’s my current code:

METHOD if_ex_mb_migo_badi~line_modify.
  IF gt_goitem[] IS NOT INITIAL.
    READ TABLE gt_goitem INTO DATA(gs_goitem) WITH KEY zeile = cs_goitem-zeile.
    IF sy-subrc <> 0.
      APPEND cs_goitem TO gt_goitem.
    ELSE.
      MODIFY gt_goitem FROM cs_goitem INDEX sy-tabix.
    ENDIF.
  ELSE.
    APPEND cs_goitem TO gt_goitem.
  ENDIF.
ENDMETHOD.

METHOD if_ex_mb_migo_badi~check_item.
  IF sy-tcode = 'MIGO'.
    DATA: lv_bsart TYPE ekko-bsart.
    LOOP AT gt_goitem ASSIGNING FIELD-SYMBOL(<cs_goitem>) 
           WHERE matnr IS NOT INITIAL AND zeile = i_line_id.
      IF <cs_goitem>-ebeln IS NOT INITIAL.
        SELECT SINGLE bsart
          INTO lv_bsart
          FROM ekko
         WHERE ebeln = <cs_goitem>-ebeln.
        IF sy-subrc = 0 AND lv_bsart = 'ZNB7'.
          <cs_goitem>-kzmhd = ''.  " Trying to disable check
        ENDIF.
      ENDIF.
    ENDLOOP.
  ENDIF.
ENDMETHOD.

I’m using a global internal table gt_goitem (type GOITEM) to store line item data.

Problem: The shelf life check is still enforced. The kzmhd flag doesn’t seem to take effect.

Question:
Is check_item the right method to suppress the shelf life check? Or should I be using malmi to modify im_t156-kzmhd?

Any guidance or corrected code example would be greatly appreciated!

Thanks in advance!
Best regards,

entry.title: Re: SAC Table - Measures disappear after setting dimensio...
entry.content:
So I played around a little bit and it turned out that those problems only occured when I used two specific measures in a chart at the same time. If I used them separately or in combination with other measures, everything worked normally.

So in Datasphere I added an exception aggregation to the measure that allegedly caused the problem. I added the dimensions by which the measures are displayed and/or filtered in the story.

That at least solved the symtoms I had. I'm still not sure about the cause though.

entry.title: Re: In SAP ECC, when manually converting a PR in a PO, PR...
entry.content:
Hello @Ana_Brrios 

Check the note 2542922 - When converting PR to PO, the item details are not copied/adopted to the PO

Cause
This behavior depends on how the Fast Processing settings are customized in transaction OMFI for a Default Values key and whether this key is assigned to EVO parameter to that particular user who performs this action/process.

Resolution
There are two scenarios:

  1. Either Reference to ref.doc or Ref. to Purchase Requisition is ticked (could be both or either of them - only in case of PR as reference document -).
    In this case, the PR item details are automatically taken over and will be filled in the PO.
  2. Neither Reference to ref.doc nor Ref. to Purchase Requisition is ticked. (Or simply the correctly customized Default Values key mentioned in option 1 is not assigned to that particular user via EVO parameter.)
    In this case, none of the PR item details are automatically copied and taken over to the PO.
    Still, the chosen purchase requisition from MD04 will be placed in the Document Overview section automatically, so you are able to select the items which you wish to convert to a PO.
    You can either use the Adopt button or you could also move the PR number via drag and drop to the purchasing basket.

Best regards

Dominik Tylczynski

entry.title: Re: Value Mapping in SAP Master Data governance MDG-M
entry.content:
Absolutely, this explanation is spot on! Value mapping in SAP MDG is indeed a critical step when integrating master data across different systems, ensuring that data remains consistent and meaningful during replication. What you’ve outlined about transforming a Division code from 30 in the source system to 35 in the target system is a perfect example of how precise value mapping supports seamless data integration.

By defining the global data type and maintaining value mapping lists, organizations can automate these conversions, reducing manual errors and ensuring data consistency across multiple systems. The step where the code list is assigned to elements and systems is particularly crucial - it guarantees that every replicated material carries the correct value in the target system, maintaining integrity in transactional data.

Using PiLog Master Data Governance, this process becomes even more streamlined. PiLog provides tools and methodologies to plan, monitor, and execute such value mappings efficiently across complex landscapes. It helps ensure that global standards are applied, transformation rules are followed consistently, and the right values flow to the right systems. By incorporating these practices, teams can maintain high-quality master data while reducing the risk of discrepancies and improving overall system integration. This approach keeps master data reliable, accurate, and fully aligned with organizational requirements.

entry.title: [Portuguese] SAP Business Data Cloud: Sessões de Expert-Guided Implementation
entry.content:
Find English Version here.

O SAP Business Data Cloud é uma solução SaaS que unifica e governa todos os dados da SAP e se conecta perfeitamente a dados de terceiros, oferecendo aos líderes de linha de negócios contexto para tomar decisões ainda mais impactantes.

A SAP está mudando a forma como os dados são compartilhados em cada uma de suas linhas de negócios usando a eficiência dos conceitos de malha de dados e cópia zero. Queremos fornecer uma abordagem de arquitetura de infraestrutura de dados verdadeira para funções analíticas. Avanços na Inteligência Artificial também ressaltaram a importância de dados limpos e semanticamente ricos. O SAP Business Data Cloud conecta todos os dados, aproveitando os princípios da infraestrutura de dados de negócios, facilitando a descoberta, o compartilhamento, a governança e o modelo de dados.

 

🚀Capacite sua jornada de dados: Apresentamos nossa nova série de SAP Business Data Fabric Workshop

No cenário digital acelerado de hoje, os dados são mais do que apenas um recurso – é um ativo estratégico. Empresas de todo o mundo estão evoluindo para tomar decisões mais rápidas, inteligentes e conectadas usando plataformas de dados modernas. Para dar suporte a essa evolução, temos o prazer de anunciar nossa renovada série de workshops Expert-Guided Implementation (EGI) do SAP Enterprise Support, desenvolvidos para ajudá-lo a aprimorar, modernizar e preparar seus recursos de dados e funções analíticas da SAP para o futuro.

Quer você queira modernizar sistemas legados, aproveitar o poder dos dados na nuvem ou desvendar insights em tempo real por meio de funções analíticas, esta série de workshops tem algo para todos.

As sessões EGI a seguir serão executadas ao longo do ano com atualizações trimestrais na programação. Há um máximo de 20 participantes individuais do cliente por sessão.

 

1. SAP Business Data Cloud Core Skills (sessões em português)

Nesta nova sessão de EGI, forneceremos uma compreensão concreta dos casos de uso do SAP Business Data Cloud e apresentaremos os recursos importantes e os componentes incluídos com a ajuda de orientação de líderes especializados para que você possa ver mais rapidamente o retorno sobre o investimento ao iniciar seu próprio projeto.

Você receberá uma análise detalhada abrangente do SAP Business Data Cloud, incluindo os aspectos mais técnicos, como Intelligent Applications, Data Products, opções de conectividade e muito mais.

Agenda:

  • Entender o valor que o SAP Business Data Cloud traz além do SAP BW, SAP Datasphere e SAP Analytics Cloud
  • Conhecer os principais recursos e componentes
  • Como utilizar Intelligent Applications para entrega rápida de soluções
  • Saber como a SAP está usando o conceito de Data Products em cada LoB
  • Possibilidades de integração com empresas SAP, não SAP e SAP Databricks
  • Roadmap da solução
  • Disponibilidade da solução
  • Essencialmente, o participante será bem informado sobre o valor que o SAP BDC pode agregar à organização e poderá utilizar Intelligent Applications de forma produtiva desde o início.

Registre-se Aqui 

 

 2. SAP BW Modernization with SAP Business Data Cloud (sessões em inglês)

Nesta sessão de EGI, forneceremos uma compreensão clara dos caminhos de transição disponíveis do SAP BW (por exemplo, BW/4HANA, BW on HANA, Private Cloud Edition etc.) para o SAP Business Data Cloud. Você receberá insights abrangentes sobre as inovações arquitetônicas agora disponíveis com o SAP Business Data Cloud.Munidos deste conhecimento, iremos guiá-lo através de estratégias práticas de migração.

Agenda:

  • Visão geral da modernização do SAP BW com o BDC e o SAP Data Product Generator
  • Inovações arquitetônicas, permitindo que os participantes conectem conceitos do SAP Business Data Cloud para modernizar o SAP BW
  • Lakehouse Architecture na Datasphere com Object Store
  • Delta Sharing com Databricks
  • SAP BW Transition Path para o SAP Business Data Cloud

Registre-se Aqui

 

3. SAP Datasphere Core Skills (sessões em inglês e em mandarim)

​ O SAP Datasphere é a solução abrangente de gerenciamento de dados que integra, governa e compartilha dados em ambientes híbridos e multinuvem, como parte do SAP Business Data Cloud.
Este workshop de EGI já está em execução desde agosto de 2024. Você pode ler uma descrição detalhada sobre neste blog anterior da SAP Community: SAP Datasphere Core Skills: Expert-Guided Implementation.
Este tópico EGI permanece relevante e atualizaremos continuamente a sessão com conteúdo relacionado ao SAP Datasphere no contexto do SAP Business Data Cloud.

Agenda:

  • Insights sobre system readiness, instalação e configuração de opções de conectividade e integração de dados
  • Democratização de dados com soluções analíticas SAP totalmente integradas
  • Modelagem de dados – analisaremos a camada de dados/camada de negócios, a modelagem e a transferência de modelo do SAP BW/4HANA
  • Provisionamento e replicação de dados
  • Gerenciamento de espaço e uso
  • Autorizações
  • Veremos o SAP HANA Database Explorer e muito mais

Nosso objetivo é que, ao longo dessas sessões de capacitação, ajude você a entender os principais conceitos e ver mais rápido o retorno sobre o investimento ao adotar o SAP Datasphere.

REGISTRE-SE AGORA

 

4. SAP Analytics Cloud BI Core Skills (sessões em português e em inglês)

Já em execução há vários anos, temos nosso EGI para SAP Analytics Cloud BI. Isso é detalhado neste blog da SAP Community: SAP Analytics Cloud - Expert-Guided Implementation
Transforme dados em insights com as poderosas ferramentas de business intelligence do SAP Analytics Cloud. Durante este EGI, você obterá uma síntese do desenvolvimento de modelo e história no SAP Analytics Cloud.
Iremos guiar você por todos os principais recursos e funcionalidades, incluindo a implementação de conteúdo da Business Content Network.
Você também será apresentado aos principais tópicos de conectividade, configuração de segurança, monitoramento e funções analíticas aumentadas e muito mais.

Agenda:

  • Entenda os benefícios e recursos do SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC).
  • Obtenha uma compreensão completa sobre o desenvolvimento e a personalização de Histórias no SAC, incluindo compartilhamento, colaboração e agendamento de publicações.
  • Orientação sobre Analytics Designer, Widgets e Mobile Apps.
  • Torne-se competente nas funções de Lifecycle Management e de administração.
  • Saiba mais sobre recursos inteligentes, Time Series Forecasting, e R Visualizations
  • Recursos novos e planejados, como JustAsk e IA generativa com o SAP Joule.

Registre-se Aqui

 

5. SAP Analytics Cloud Planning Core Skills (sessões em inglês, espanhol, português e mandarim)

Da mesma forma, já estamos executando nosso EGI no SAP Analytics Cloud for Planning. Isso também está detalhado neste blog da SAP Community: SAP Analytics Cloud - Expert-Guided Implementation
O planejamento atende à inteligência nesta sessão prática focada nos recursos de SAC Planning. Durante esse EGI, obterá uma visão geral dos recursos de planejamento no SAP Analytics Cloud.
Você compreenderá os principais recursos do Enterprise Planning com o SAP Analytics Cloud e demonstrará a integração com recursos de Business Intelligence e Augmented Analytics features.
Você verá como importar dados transacionais para um modelo a partir de um arquivo e criar um modelo de planejamento no SAP Analytics Cloud junto com o Predictive Forecasting.

Agenda

  • Visão geral dos recursos do SAP Analytics Cloud e do Planning
  • Version Management, Planning Panel, e Variance Analysis
  • Compreender Advanced Formulas & Scripting knowledge
  • Predictive Forecasting, recursos de colaboração e muito mais
  • Ações e alocações de dados
  • SAP Planning Solutions integradas – Application Designer, cenários híbridos, conteúdo empresarial, análise para Office, etc.

Registre-se Aqui

 

Quem deve se inscrever?

Esta série de workshops é ideal para profissionais de dados, consultores, analistas de negócios, integradores de sistemas e clientes da SAP que desejam nivelar seus dados em nuvem e conhecimento analítico. Não importa se você está apenas começando ou quer se aprofundar no moderno conjunto de ferramentas da SAP, há uma sessão adaptada às suas necessidades.

 

Suporte adicional e capacitação via SAP Enterprise Support Value Maps

entry.title: Re: Need Help with MB_MIGO_BADI Enhancement – Skip Shelf...
entry.content:
With the standard functionality, when MIGO is executed, internally, it validates the data from T156S and material master data to determine whether shelf life data is mandatory. The system may still enforce the check based on batch management settings or movement type control, even if you clear KZMHD.

Consider using the IF_EX_MB_MIGO_BADI~MALMI method. This method allows you to influence the movement type data, specifically the structure IM_T156, which includes the KZMHD flag.

See that the batch management is not enforcing shelf life independently via MCHA-HSDAT. For some reasons, if the material is batch-managed and shelf life is mandatory in the material master, you may need to override batch master logic via BAdI VB_SLED_MANAGEMENT or MB_BATCH_MASTER. Finally, and importantly, test always with debugging breakpoints in MALMI to confirm that your logic is being triggered before the shelf life check.

entry.title: Copy billing plan of KMAT material to Finished goods in same Sales order via create with reference
entry.content:
We have a scenario in SAP Public cloud where the billing plan of materials at line item needs to be copied within the same sales order. Could you please advise on how to achieve the copying of the billing plan from the KMAT material at line item to the Finished Goods material for below process?

  1. In the Change Sales Order transaction, the KMAT (configurable material) with item category CBTD should be selected, and then Create with Reference should be used.
  2. This triggers variant matching. A custom development matches the corresponding Finished Goods material with the same variant, assigned item category CBAO. The new line item is added to the sales order. Quantity and pricing (PPR0) are correctly copied.
  3. The item billing plan from the original KMAT line does not get copied to the new line item. Instead, a header billing plan checkbox appears in the new line item: This checkbox was not present in the original line item. As a result: The billing plan section is greyed out.

entry.title: Exploring SAP Salesforce Adapter - retry mechanism with JMS queue
entry.content:
Overview :

This blog will focus on the error handling mechanism when there is connectivity error with Salesforce while trying to update/upsert data in Salesforce. We chose to opt for JMS queue.

Kindly go through previous blog to understand SAP Salesforce Adapter configuration for different operations - https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-members/exploring-salesforce-adapter-for-sap-integration-suite/ba-p/14206977

Retry Mechanism
1. JMS Queues
- Stores failed messages in queues for retries.
- Setup: Enable JMS (Enterprise Edition). Use JMS receiver to store messages. Set max 5 retries, exponential backoff. Move to dead-letter queue or notify after max retries.
- Use Case: Update failure in Salesforce Custom Object

- Pros: Reliable, visible in Queue Monitor.
- Cons: 10 GB limit, polling may pause.
- Example: Failed message retried 5 times, then mail to Application Maintenance (AM/Support) Team.

Execution Design Steps : 

1. Design consists of three iFlow -  Parent (Trigger) iFlow -> Child iFlow -> JMS Retry PD iFlow

2.Parent iFlow gets triggered whenever data is placed into Salesforce push topic

3.Child iFlow, set the /TargetFlowAddress which would be reference for the JMS Retry PD iFlow

4.In the Exception Subprocess, add router condition for specific frequent error occurring during update operation in Salesforce

5.On router condition match, call the JMS Retry PD iflow with the input push topic payload 

6. In JMS Retry PD iFlow - after max retry attempt trigger mail to the AM team.

Implementation Steps : Below are configuration snippets 

CHILD FLOW :

1. set target address of the iflow to be retriggered by JMS Retry PD iflow ;  in child flow  in content modifier as

2. Exception occurred in Child flow - 

Exception subprocess in Child flow captures the error using the script 

 

 

JMS Retry PD Flow

3. JMS Retry PD Flow is triggered for the initial store with custom header set message as shown below

Setting queue name

4.In LIP for JMS Reprocess assign the queue name and set the retry mode for iteration check 

5. Using the target address call the child flow where error occurred for retry attempts - as shown below -

 

6. In case the reprocessing fails, then exception subprocess calls the LIP_ReprocessFailedMessage

7. After Max retry attempts, mail gets triggered from JMS Retry PD iflow.

PARENT FLOW : 

8.Flow execution goes back to parents in the exception subprocess of parent flow.

9. Set the iflow name in content modifier for mail body. 

10. Router condition checks on the specific error and routes accordingly. In case of 'UNABLE_TO_LOCK_ROW' , ends it since JMS Retry PD already sent the error notification mail. In case of other error, sends the error notification mail.

 

 

Monitoring Log : 

Below would be reflected

First Initial Store in JMS is set as custom execution header message in JMS Retry PD iflow then attempts in child flow then sends the mail after max attempt and set the error as the custom execution header message.

For groovy for execution summary mail body, you can refer to the previous blog - 

https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-members/interface-execution-summary-exception-alert-for-logging-monitoring-and/ba-p/14165906

entry.title: Re: HOWTO redirect and/or filter sapgenpse output
entry.content:
Hello,

Thank you very much for your question and sorry for the late reply.

Can you please check whether the following information (GenAI was used to help generate this content) solves your issue?

It seems that the sapgenpse command does not support standard output redirection or filtering using typical shell techniques like >, 2>&1, or tee. This can indeed make scripting challenging if you need to capture its output for further processing.

Here are a few suggestions you might try:

  1. Use a Wrapper Script: Create a wrapper script that captures the output of sapgenpse using a tool like expect or script. These tools can capture terminal output and save it to a file.

  2. Log Output: If sapgenpse has a logging option, you might be able to direct its output to a log file directly.

  3. Check for Updates or Alternatives: Sometimes newer versions of a tool or alternative tools might offer better support for scripting and output redirection.

Unfortunately, without specific support from sapgenpse for output redirection, these workarounds might be necessary.

 
Kind regards,

Henrike

SSL Setup Wizard

entry.title: Re: Global Class Static Attribute
entry.content:
Hello,

Thank you very much for your question and sorry for the late reply.

Can you please check whether the following information (GenAI was used to help generate this content) solves your issue?

When dealing with static attributes in global classes, one common issue is the lifecycle of the class instance. Static attributes are shared across all instances of a class, but they are reset if the class is reloaded or if the program context changes.

In your scenario, the static attribute might be getting reset between the execution of EXIT_SAPLVEDA_001 and USER_EXIT_SAVE_DOCUMENT. This can happen if the class is reloaded or if there is a change in the program context.

Alternative Approaches

  1. Ensure Class Persistence:

    • Make sure that the class instance is not being reloaded or reset between the two exits. This might involve checking how the class is being used and ensuring it remains in memory.

  2. Use a Singleton Pattern:

    • Implement a singleton pattern for your class to ensure that the same instance is used throughout the program execution.

  3. Consider Using a Database Table or Persistent Object:

    • If you want to avoid using Memory ID, consider storing the value in a database table or using a persistent object. This way, the value can be retrieved reliably across different program contexts.

Unfortunately, without using Memory ID or a similar mechanism, ensuring persistence of static attributes across different exits can be challenging due to the nature of program execution in SAP systems.

Kind regards,

Henrike

entry.title: Dashboard and Business AI Insights for SAP License Simulation and Analysis
entry.content:
Introduction

SAP has introduced the SAM4U solution, an excellent tool to gather data from SAP backend systems for the consolidation and analysis of users, engines, and HANA EE license consumption.

The Accelerator for SAM4U Adoption, available on SAP Store, provides extended analytics and simulation capabilities to view SAM4U data from new angles. It empowers customers moving to S/4HANA, S/4HANA Private Cloud, or already working under an SAP RISE contract to run different “what if” scenarios based on data extracted from their SAP system, helping them find the best approach to optimize SAP license consumption.

What Was Missing?

While SAM4U provides valuable transparency, customers often asked:

  • How do I see the potential savings?

  • How do I define a strategy for optimization?

  • Where exactly should I focus my cleanup efforts?

License optimization typically falls into three categories:

  • Fast optimization: achieved quickly with user data cleanup in SAP backend

  • Obtainable optimization: achievable in reasonable time with cleanup and role/profile tuning

  • Maximal optimization: the long-term goal, achieved when roles and authorizations are precisely aligned with actual usage

What was missing was clarity and insights to navigate these paths effectively.

How it is solved

The new release of the Accelerator for SAM4U Adoption brings two major updates:

  • Clarity through an extremely informative dashboard

  • Business AI insights powered by the Skybuffer AI platform, an SAP Business AI certified solution from SAP Store

The dashboard

This is the highlight. The dashboard presents clear KPIs on one page, helping to get insights into current estimated spending and estimated savings, following both fast and obtainable strategies.

 Pic. 1 The Dashboard

One of the central KPIs is License Optimization Potential, which shows the estimated current contract costs compared to optimized contract costs. The KPI highlights savings that can be achieved either through the fast users cleanup approach or the obtainable approach of cleaning up users and optimizing roles with the highest optimization potential.

 Pic. 2 License Optimization Potential

There are many other useful insights. For example, it shows how many authorization objects are not used at all. This is a target for maximal optimization and one reason it is not so easily obtainable. The lower the number, the better the authorizations are aligned with active usage.

 Pic. 3 Excess Authorization

The evaluation of maximal optimization is also visualized by the FUE Gap KPI:

 Pic. 4 FUE Gap - Authorization vs Active Usage

There is also a very helpful hint about SAP_ALL and SAP_NEW profiles still in use in production:

 Pic. 5 Users with Sensitive Authorization Profiles

The total number of roles and profiles that can be optimized and the savings this brings are also clearly summarized:

 Pic. 6 Excess Roles

The insights

Business AI insights in the dashboard bring extra clarity and understanding. For example, they show the fast optimization saving potential and provide clear explanations and strategies on how to reach it:

Pic. 7 Business AI Insights

AI recommendations are also available for obtainable or maximal optimization:

 Pic. 8 Max and Obtainable Optimization

Effectively, this functions as a personal SAP License Analysis and Optimization consultant, virtualized and trained to understand the organization’s own data.

The AI Assistant is always there, and expanding its knowledge base is straightforward through the Skybuffer AI platform. For example, it can present the top 10 roles for optimization or provide additional information related to SAP licensing:

 Pic. 9 Top 10 Roles for Optimization

Of course, all the well-established simulation and analysis tools of the Accelerator remain available. With the new release, they work even better, helping to test and simulate the AI Assistant’s recommendations.

Conclusion

The Accelerator for SAM4U Adoption now provides one of the most powerful toolsets on the market to analyze and optimize SAP users and engines licenses independently. It helps avoid the significant costs of SAP license optimization consulting and delivers deep insights into user and engine data. This comes without the need for a complex SAM4U installation and without spending time and money on consulting services that quickly become outdated.

What to do next?

Running SAP under a RISE contract? Use the dashboard and Business AI insights at least once per month to avoid FUE consumption increases and surprises. Train your team with the solution and the organization will not face unpredictable growth of SAP license consumption. Leave consulting for the exceptional case when the company grows faster than its SAP role set. 😉

entry.title: Re: Getting Tax item missing for tax code error from BAPI...
entry.content:
Hello,

Thank you very much for your question and sorry for the late reply.

Can you please check whether the following information (GenAI was used to help generate this content) solves your issue?

When using the BAPI_ACC_DOCUMENT_POST and encountering the error ‘Tax item missing for tax code’, it is often due to the absence of tax data in the BSET internal table. This typically happens when zero tax is sent, leading to the error.

Solution

To resolve this issue, ensure that the tax code is correctly set and that the tax items are properly calculated and included in the BSET table. Here are some steps you can follow:

  1. Check Tax Code Validity: Ensure that the tax code used is valid and falls within the correct validity period. If the tax code has various validity periods, Posting Journal Entries with Tax Using SOAP Posting APIs you may need to specify a tax determination date.

  2. Include Tax Line Items: Even if the tax amount is zero, you should still include the tax line items in your payload. This involves setting the necessary fields such as Tax Code, Tax Classification, and Tax Base Amount.

  3. Use Correct Tax Calculation Method: If your system requires tax calculation by line items, ensure that this is activated and that tax items are determined individually for each item.

  4. Review Configuration: Check the configuration settings for your tax accounts and ensure that they are set to allow posting without tax if G/L account requires a valid tax code necessary.

By following these steps, you should be able to resolve the error and successfully post your document using BAPI_ACC_DOCUMENT_POST.

[1] Posting Journal Entries with Tax Using SOAP Posting APIs
[2] G/L account requires a valid tax code

Kind regards,

Henrike

entry.title: Re: Diff b/w EkkN-AUFPL and EKKN-AUFPL_ORD
entry.content:
Hello,

Thank you very much for your question and sorry for the late reply.

Can you please check whether the following information (GenAI was used to help generate this content) solves your issue?

In the SAP table EKKN, the fields AUFPL and AUFPL_ORD serve different purposes related to network operations and routing.

AUFPL

  • AUFPL is typically used to store the routing number or operation sequence number associated with a network activity. This field is crucial for identifying the sequence of operations within a network.

AUFPL_ORD

  • AUFPL_ORD is used to store the order-related routing number or operation sequence number. This field may sometimes be blank if the operation is not directly linked to an order or if the order-related routing is not applicable.

The presence of values in AUFPL_ORD depends on whether the network operation is associated with a specific order. If the operation is purely network-related without direct order linkage, AUFPL_ORD might be empty.

Understanding the distinction between these fields is important for accurately extracting and analyzing network-related operations in SAP.

Kind regards,

Henrike

entry.title: Re: need to add additional columns in PM task list compon...
entry.content:
Hello,

Thank you very much for your question and sorry for the late reply.

Can you please check whether the following information (GenAI was used to help generate this content) solves your issue?

To add columns such as ‘Outline Agreement’, ‘Agreement Item’, and ‘Info Records’ to the PM Task List component section, you can use the Data Source Extensions feature in SAP S/4HANA Cloud. This allows you to enhance the standard Fiori UIs by including fields that are not available by default.

Steps to Add Columns:

  1. Access Custom Fields and Logic App:

    • Navigate to the SAP Fiori Launchpad and open the Custom Fields Invoice Management - Manage Supplier Line Items: FAQ and Logic app.

  2. Create Data Source Extension:

    • Click on the Data Source Extensions Receivables Management - Manage Customer Line Items: FAQ tab.
    • Use the ‘+’ icon to create a new data source extension.
    • Select the relevant data source associated with the PM Task List component section.

  3. Select Fields:

    • In the available fields tree, navigate to the fields you want to add, such as ‘Outline Agreement’, ‘Agreement Item’, and ‘Info Records’.
    • Select these fields and they will appear in the Selected Fields section.

  4. Customize Field Labels:

    • You can change the field label and tooltip text by selecting the Custom Text checkbox and entering your desired text.

  5. Publish Extension:

    • Once you have selected and customized the fields, publish the extension.
    • The new fields will be available for all users in the PM Task List component section.

Note:

  • Ensure you have the necessary authorization to perform these actions.
  • If the fields are not available in the data source, you may need to check if they can be added through custom fields or logic.

For more detailed guidance, refer to the SAP documentation on Data Source Extensions and Custom Fields.

Kind regards,

Henrike

[1] Invoice Management - Manage Supplier Line Items: FAQ
[2] Receivables Management - Manage Customer Line Items: FAQ

entry.title: Re: Service Master Template Price Column in Sap S/4Hana P...
entry.content:
Hello,

Thank you very much for your question and sorry for the late reply.

Can you please check whether the following information (GenAI was used to help generate this content) solves your issue?

In SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud Edition, the handling of price control and standard price for services differs from the traditional ECC or on-premise versions. The presence of a price control column in the service master template is due to the system’s capability to manage different types of price controls, such as ‘S’ for Standard Price and ‘V’ for Moving Average Price. However, the actual entry of standard prices is managed differently.

The template includes a price control column to allow users to specify the type of price control applicable to the service. This is important for determining how price variances are handled during transactions. However, the entry of the actual standard price is not done through the template but rather through specific apps or transactions designed for price management.

In SAP S/4HANA Cloud, the standard price functionality is available, but it is typically managed through apps like ‘Set Service Prices - Sales’ Sales - Set Service Prices - Sales or ‘Manage Prices - Sales’, where you can create and maintain condition records for service prices. These apps allow you to set prices based on various conditions and criteria, such as sales organization, distribution channel, and material number.

The absence of a column for entering the standard price directly in the service master template reflects the shift towards using condition records and pricing apps for more dynamic and flexible price management. This approach allows for more granular control over pricing based on business data and conditions rather than static entries in a template.

For more detailed management of prices, users can utilize the ‘Manage Prices - Sales’ Professional Services - Manage Prices app, which provides functionalities to create, change, and display condition records used for service prices, ensuring that pricing is accurately reflected in service transactions.

Kind regards,

Henrike

[1] Sales - Set Service Prices - Sales
[2] Professional Services - Manage Prices

Can you please check whether the following information (GenAI was used to help generate this content) solves your issue?

Creating CDS (Core Data Services) views or AMDP (ABAP Managed Database Procedures) on top of open ODS views is not directly mentioned in the provided context. Open ODS views are typically used in SAP BW systems to integrate data from various sources, including non-SAP systems, into the BW environment. CDS views are primarily used in SAP S/4HANA environments to define data models and expose them as OData services or for analytical purposes.

While the context does not explicitly state the possibility of creating CDS or AMDP on top of open ODS views, it is generally possible to integrate data from open ODS views into CDS views if the data is accessible within the SAP environment. This would typically involve using the data sources available in the SAP system to define the CDS views, which can then be used for various purposes such as reporting or analytics.

Kind regards,

Henrike

entry.title: Turn spaghetti into structure: a hands-on guide to Object-Centric Clustering in SAP Signavio
entry.content:
A step-by-step guide to transforming messy process graphs into actionable insights with Object-Centric Clustering in Lab Space.

Introduction

Messy event logs and overloaded graphs can make even mature process mining initiatives hard to interpret and slow to act on. Object-Centric Process Visualization restructures those “spaghetti” views into focused, object-based clusters so you can zero in on the issues that matter. In this post, you’ll get a quick intro and a step-by-step walkthrough you can try in Lab Space.

Before you start (prerequisites)

To access Object-Centric Process Visualization in Lab Space, you’ll need an Enterprise or Enterprise Plus license and a Test and Evaluation Agreement in place. You can explore the full prototype with the included demo datasets regardless of your license, or visualize your own processes with a few limitations: full blocker/recommendation functionality requires a Plug-and-Gain license, and if your event naming standards differ from Plug-and-Gain you won’t see Business-Object level grouping.

Step-by-step: from chaos to clarity

1) Open the process graph

In Lab Space, open Object-Centric Clustering. A process graph loads automatically—no input needed. From the drop-down, you can also select the second graph to view process execution in a US branch.

 

2) Read the groupings (colored rectangles)

Colored rectangles represent groups of events that belong to the same business object. For example, a Supplier invoice group can include events like Create invoice and Move invoice immediately to free for payment. This grouping immediately adds structure to complex data.

3) Collapse or expand to tame complexity

Use the arrow icon at the top-right of any group to collapse or expand it. Collapsing reduces visual overload by hiding the individual event names while preserving context. Collapsed groups inherit the color of the highest-urgency blocker they contain, so severity remains visible at a glance. 

4) Review blockers and recommendations in context

Events carry color-coded blockers that signal improvement potential:

Red = high (affecting >10% of cases), Yellow = medium (~5–10%). Selecting a Blocker opens a pop-up with:

  • Top panel metrics (percentage and number of documents affected, plus total documents),

  • Benchmarks showing where the issue occurs (e.g., by Company Code or Transaction Code),

  • Correction and Innovation recommendations when available.

  • Tip: to see recommendations, use Supplier invoice issuing to FI-AP clearing (US) and open the event Clear FI-AP items.

Why this matters

Object-Centric Process Visualization focuses your analysis on the key process challenges, turning complex graphs into insightful, relevant views so you can identify issues and opportunities faster.

Try it now

Ready to experience it hands-on? Open Object-Centric Clustering in SAP Signavio Lab Space and walk through the steps above with the demo datasets—then bring in your own data to explore. (Feature availability depends on your license and naming conventions, as noted in the prerequisites.)

entry.title: Re: ME52N closed document going in editable mode BAPI_REQ...
entry.content:
Hello,

Thank you very much for your question and sorry for the late reply.

Can you please check whether the following information (GenAI was used to help generate this content) solves your issue?

The behavior you are experiencing with the Purchase Requisition (PR) being editable even after being marked as closed can be attributed to the standard system design and the specific conditions under which the PRs are processed.

Production Order Scenario Purchase Order change output is generated even if the PURCHASINGDOCUMENTDELETIONCODE is disable.

In the case of PRs related to production orders, the system might have additional checks or settings that prevent editing once the PR is marked as closed. This could be due to specific configurations or business rules that apply to production-related documents.

Other Scenarios Issues and recommendation related to Workflow for …

For other types of PRs, even if the ‘closed’ indicator is set, the system might allow editing due to different configurations or lack of specific restrictions that apply to production orders. This behavior is consistent with the standard SAP system design where certain fields or indicators might not prevent editing unless explicitly configured.

Possible Solutions

  1. Functional Configuration: Check if there are specific configurations or business rules that need to be applied to non-production order PRs to prevent editing once closed.
  2. SAP System Design: It might be necessary to review SAP’s standard behavior and see if any custom logic or additional settings can be implemented to achieve the desired non-editable state for all PRs.

Recommendations

  • Consult with your SAP functional consultant to review the configurations related to PRs and ensure that the necessary settings are applied to prevent editing.
  • Consider implementing additional checks or custom logic in the BAPI or related processes to enforce non-editability for closed PRs across all scenarios.

Images

 
 

Kind regards,

Henrike

entry.title: Re: In the scope item 5D2,why a company have to create tw...
entry.content:
In your case, BP A2 is created with Customer role FLCU01 and assigned to Sales Area. The sales order and intercompany billing require a customer BP that is valid in that sales area. Plants are the logistical entities that receive goods, and SAP treats them as the "Customer" in intercompany sales. BP A1, representing the company code, is not assigned to a sales area and therefore cannot be used as the customer in a sales document. Even though Company A is the legal entity receiving the goods, SAP needs a customer BP tied to the plant to process the sales-side intercompany invoice correctly.

entry.title: Istio Moves to Native Sidecars
entry.content:
Introduction

Since version 1.28, Kubernetes has offered native sidecar functionality, and Istio 1.27 uses it by default for istio-proxy sidecars. Native sidecars will enabled by default also in the Istio module 1.22, which is part of SAP BTP, Kyma runtime.

Let's see what are the benefits of native sidecars, learn how to use them, and understand what hacks can be removed.

Differences Between Regular and Native Sidecar Containers

Every Pod in the Istio mesh gets an additional istio-proxy sidecar container, which intercepts network traffic to provide Istio features.

In the past, Kubernetes didn't support the concept of sidecar containers, so it wasn't possible to control the order in which containers within a Pod were started or stopped. This approach causes multiple issues, such as:

  • When an application container starts before the istio-proxy sidecar container is ready, the application doesn't have network access at startup.
  • When the istio-proxy sidecar stops before the application container stops, the application loses network access during shutdown.
  • An init container runs before the istio-proxy sidecar container, so it can't access the network.
  • A running istio-proxy sidecar container prevents Pods from being finished (for example, in the case of Jobs).

Since version 1.28, Kubernetes has offered native sidecar containers functionality to address such problems. If an init container has restartPolicy set to Always, Kubernetes considers it a native sidecar and treats it differently. Istio uses native sidecars introduced by Kubernetes for istio-proxy sidecars. See Kubernetes Native Sidecars in Istio.

Default Istio Proxy Sidecar Type

The Istio module (part of SAP BTP, Kyma runtime) configures the default type of the istio-proxy sidecar container, which is injected into all Pods that allow for Istio sidecar proxy injection. However, you can override this default setting for a specific Pod, allowing it to use another type of sidecar container regardless of the Istio module’s default configuration. The default istio-proxy sidecar type varies depending on the particular Istio module and Istio version:

  • Istio module up to 1.20 - native sidecars are disabled by default
  • Istio module 1.21 with Istio 1.27 - native sidecars are disabled by default
  • Istio module 1.22 with Istio 1.27 - native sidecars are enabled by default, unless you set compatibilityMode in the Istio CR to true
  • Istio module with Istio 1.28 - native sidecars are enabled by default

Configuring the Type of Istio Sidecar Proxy for a Particular Workload

You can configure the sidecar type explicitly for a particular workload.

  • To inject istio-proxy as a native sidecar container, set the sidecar.istio.io/nativeSidecar annotation to "true" on a given Pod or in the Pod template.
  • To inject istio-proxy as a regular sidecar container, set the sidecar.istio.io/nativeSidecar annotation to "false" on a given Pod or in the Pod template.

If you do not set the annotation, the default setting is used.

You must set the annotation at the Pod level. So, when a Pod is created by a parent resource (for example, Deployment, StatefulSet, ReplicaSet, DaemonSet, Job, CronJob), you must configure the annotation in the Pod template. See the example:

apiVersion: apps/v1
kind: Deployment
metadata:
  name: test-deployment
spec:
  template:
    metadata:
      annotations:
        sidecar.istio.io/nativeSidecar: "true"
...

Setting the sidecar type explicitly is especially recommended when a given workload works well only with one sidecar type and causes issues otherwise. This approach guarantees that the sidecar type doesn't change after the Istio module upgrade. A good example are Job Pods, which can't finish if the main container finishes because the istio-proxy sidecar container is still running. In this case, setting the sidecar.istio.io/nativeSidecar annotation in the Pod template solves the problem.

Support in the Istio Module

The Istio module (part of SAP BTP, Kyma runtime) fully supports both types of sidecar containers. In particular, in case of Istio version update it detects which workloads should be restarted and this mechanism works with both sidecar types.

Example of Istio Proxy as Native Sidecar

  1. Create a test namespace with Istio injection enabled:

    kubectl create ns test
kubectl label namespace test istio-injection=enabled

  2. Create a workload with istio-proxy running as a native sidecar container:

    kubectl apply -f - <<EOF
apiVersion: batch/v1
kind: Job
metadata:
  name: test-job
  namespace: test
spec:
  template:
    metadata:
      annotations:
        sidecar.istio.io/nativeSidecar: "true"
    spec:
      containers:
      - name: test-job
        image: alpine:latest
        command: [ "/bin/sleep", "10" ]
      restartPolicy: Never
EOF

  3. To observe the progress, run:

    kubectl get pod -n test -w
    NAME             READY   STATUS     RESTARTS   AGE
test-job-2tt95   0/2     Init:0/2   0          0s
test-job-2tt95   0/2     Init:1/2   0          1s
test-job-2tt95   0/2     Init:1/2   0          2s
test-job-2tt95   0/2     PodInitializing   0          10s
test-job-2tt95   1/2     PodInitializing   0          10s
test-job-2tt95   2/2     Running           0          11s
test-job-2tt95   1/2     Completed         0          21s
test-job-2tt95   0/2     Completed         0          22s

    The key differences when compared to the istio-proxy run as a regular sidecar container:

    • When the Pod starts, it has the Init status with two containers.
    • The application container only starts after the istio-proxy native sidecar is fully operational.
    • After the main container completes its job, the Pod finishes with the status Completed.
  4. List init containers:
    kubectl get pod -n test -o jsonpath='{.items[0].spec.initContainers[*].name}'

    The output contains two containers, and istio-proxy is now an init container:

    istio-validation istio-proxy

  5. List regular containers:

    kubectl get pod -n test -o jsonpath='{.items[0].spec.containers[*].name}'

    The output includes only the application container without istio-proxy:

    test-job

Known Hacks that Native Sidecars Can Replace

The /quitquitquit call

The solution was proposed under issue #6324.

The istio-proxy sidecar offers an additional endpoint /quitquitquit that you can use in the following way to shut down istio-proxy:

curl -sf -XPOST http://127.0.0.1:15020/quitquitquit

Using the endpoint is no longer required if istio-proxy runs as a native sidecar. Its lifecycle is bound to the main application container, so the istio-proxy sidecar shuts down automatically when the main container is finished.

runAsUser 1337, or excludeOutboundIPRanges, or excludeOutboundPorts

The solution was proposed in the blog post Upcoming breaking change in SAP BTP, Kyma Runtime: Enabling the Istio CNI plugin.

Init containers are started before regular containers are started. This means that the istio-proxy as regular sidecar doesn't work when init containers are running. As a result init containers don't have network access.

By configuring UID 1337, excludeOutboundIPRanges, or excludeOutboundPorts you can exclude the network traffic from being captured by the istio-proxy. This allows init containers to access the network, but they are able to connect only to resources outside service mesh.

This is no longer required if istio-proxy runs as a native sidecar because the istio-proxy is injected as the first init container and runs until the main application container finishes. So, init containers are able to access the network in the same way as regular application containers, and they may connect to resources inside and outside the service mesh.

Summary

Native sidecars are a good step forward that solves a lot of issues that developers had with regular sidecar containers. They simplify the application orchestration because you don't need to think about the order in which containers are started, and you don't need to implement workarounds for non-working istio-proxy or for Pod termination.

Related Links

  • Kubernetes blog post about native sidecars
  • Istio blog post about native sidecars

entry.title: Re: MARDH in S/4HANA showing lot of entries compared to ECC
entry.content:
The possible reason could be MARDH is updated from MATDOC_EXTRACT which is part of the New Simplified Data Model. This model records every material document line, even if the quantity doesn’t change across periods. So even if the stock remains unchanged, S/4HANA still generates entries for each period, leading to massive data inflation.

To avoid the performance issue, may be you can consider using MATDOC table for reporting.

entry.title: New Learning Journey Integrating SAP Sales Cloud and SAP Service Cloud Version 2 with SAP S/4HANA
entry.content:
Hey SAP CX Community! It's Fernando here, checking in!

Over the past few years, we've been creating numerous educational resources focused on integration topics for SAP Sales and Service Cloud version 1.  From this year on, our upcoming focus will be on version 2 extensibility and integration topics. Today, we are thrilled to announce in this blog post the next major learning milestone for those looking to master the integration of SAP Sales and Service Cloud version 2 with SAP S/4HANA.

Join me in welcoming our newest addition to the SAP's learning platform: 


New Learning Journey 
Integrating SAP Sales Cloud and SAP Service Cloud Version 2 with SAP S/4HANA

If you're an integration developer looking to prepare for integrating SAP Sales and Service Cloud version 2 with SAP S/4HANA using Cloud Integration, you've come to the right place. Here, you'll gain the practical knowledge needed to manage the entire end-to-end integration project.

We've structured our content to ensure that, after finishing this learning journey, integration developers, administrators, and consultants will have the skills to set up, configure, and implement the integration between SAP Sales and Service Cloud version 2 and SAP S/4HANA for master data replication.

Here's a sneak peek of how it appears:

Audience
The course is meant to be helpful for:

  • Integration Developers
  • Technical Consultants
  • Administrators
  • Architects

Learning Objectives
After completing this learning journey, integration developers and technical consultants will gain an overview of the fundamental technical aspects, architecture, and scenarios for the integration between SAP Sales and Service Cloud Version 2, and SAP S/4HANA. You will be able to develop end-to-end integration between these systems based on identifying involved systems, exploring integration scenarios, preparing your system landscape, performing the master data replication procedure, and gaining skills on monitoring and troubleshooting techniques.

Learning Content
The learning journey consists of 6 units and provides more than 8 hours of content:

  • Introducing the Integration of SAP Sales Cloud and SAP Service Cloud Version 2 with SAP S/4HANA
    This unit introduces SAP Sales and Service Cloud integration with SAP S/4HANA, covering SAP's integration strategy, involved systems, standard scenarios, and the course's scope..
  • Preparing Technical System Settings
    Covers the preparation of technical system settings for integrating SAP Sales and Service Cloud with SAP S/4HANA, including detailed system landscape exploration, communication settings, credential setup, integration package configuration, trust establishment, and Cloud Connector configuration.
  • Preparing Functional Dependencies in SAP Sales Cloud and SAP Service Cloud Version 2
    This unit focuses on preparing functional dependencies in SAP Sales and Service Cloud, including examining object dependencies, understanding external ID mapping and code list maintenance, and setting up code list integration using Incoterms as an example.
  • Setting Up and Running Product Replication from SAP S/4HANA to SAP Sales Cloud and SAP Service Cloud Version 2
    Teaches how to set up and run product replication from SAP S/4HANA to SAP Sales and Service Cloud, including configuring communication settings, integration flows, web services, and executing the replication process.
  • Setting Up and Running Business Partner Replication from SAP S/4HANA to SAP Sales Cloud and SAP Service Cloud Version 2
    This unit covers setting up and running business partner replication from SAP S/4HANA to SAP Sales and Service Cloud, including configuring communication settings, integration flows, service groups, data replication framework, business partner confirmation, and executing the replication process.
  • Monitoring Messages and Troubleshooting
    Last unit on monitoring messages and troubleshooting in the integration process between SAP S/4HANA and SAP Sales and Service Cloud, including identifying monitoring tools, analyzing common issues, and resolving them effectively.

entry.title: Re: Is there any reason to purchase SAP BTP when using SA...
entry.content:
Hello @redhorse 

Thank you for reaching out to The SAP Community, and for your questions. Below are the answers and steps, and SAP Documentation that will help you achieve your goal

RAP on S/4HANA Cloud (Public): Is it possible to create Z* tables?
Yes. With Developer Extensibility (ABAP Cloud), you develop on-stack via ADT (ABAP Development Tools), and you can create objects in the customer namespace (Z*) and expose them with RAP (RESTful ABAP Programming) within ABAP Cloud guardrails (released APIs only, clean core).
Key references: SAP Help on connecting ADT to S/4HANA Cloud ABAP environment; customer namespace usage. ABAP Cloud FAQ.

SAP Help Portal-Connect to the ABAP System 

SAP Community ABAP Cloud FAQ

Do I also require SAP BTP (Business Technology Platform)?
Not by default. Utilise embedded ABAP Cloud for extensions closely linked to S/4HANA (RAP apps, small services, validations) that can coexist with S/4HANA's lifecycle. opt for SAP BTP (side-by-side) when you require independent lifecycle/scaling, multi-system applications, partner-facing UIs, Integration Suite, Event Mesh, API management, AI/ML, or to develop SaaS on the BTP ABAP environment.


Key references include Side-by-Side Extensibility for S/4HANA Cloud, SAP’s extension architecture guidance, and the Extensibility Explorer scenarios.

SAP Help Portal-Side-by-Side Extensibility

SAP Extensibility Explorer for SAP S/4HANA Cloud

The final point

You can directly create Z* tables and RAP applications in S/4HANA Cloud (Public).

Use or purchase BTP when your use case requires side-by-side capabilities or additional BTP services; otherwise, embedded ABAP Cloud should be enough.

Develop extensions for SAP S/4HANA with SAP BTP, ABAP Environment, and runtime

Feel free to contact me if you need further information.

With kind regards

Chuma

entry.title: Protect Your SAP S/4HANA from Critical Code Injection Vulnerability [CVE-2025-42957]
entry.content:
Protect Your SAP S/4HANA from Critical Code Injection Vulnerability [CVE-2025-42957] with SAP Enterprise Threat Detection and SAP Enterprise Threat Detection, cloud edition.

A critical ABAP code injection vulnerability (CVE-2025-42957) has been discovered in SAP S/4HANA (Private Cloud or On-Premise), exposing SAP systems to potential exploits. This vulnerability allows attackers with user privileges to inject arbitrary ABAP code, bypassing essential authorization checks and putting the entire system at risk of compromise.

Key Details:

  • Vulnerability ID: CVE-2025-42957

  • CVSS v3.0 Base Score: 9.9 / 10

  • Impacted Components: S4CORE 102 - 108

Understanding the Threat:

This flaw operates as a backdoor, allowing unauthorized access to SAP systems and jeopardizing confidentiality, integrity, and availability. Without immediate mitigation, your SAP S/4HANA system could be severely compromised.

Monitoring with SAP Enterprise Threat Detection (SAP ETD):

SAP Enterprise Threat Detection plays a crucial role in identifying and mitigating such vulnerabilities. By adding the function module /SLOAE/DEPLOY to the value list ABAP Blocklisted Function Modules, SAP Enterprise Threat Detection can monitor and flag potential exploitation of this vulnerability.

Additionally, SAP Enterprise Threat Detection can be configured to track the frequency and context of calls to this critical function module. In a recent review of a production system landscape containing 34bn log events it was observed that this function module was not called at all over the last several months, validating its inclusion in threat detection parameters avoiding fals positives.

Steps to Secure Your SAP System:

  1. Patch Installation: Apply the correction instructions or support packages referenced by SAP Note 3627998 to eliminate code injection risks today!

  2. SAP Enterprise Threat Detection Monitoring: Add /SLOAE/DEPLOY to ABAP Blocklisted Function Modules in SAP Enterprise Threat Detection to monitor attempts to exploit this vulnerability.

  3. System Audits: Regularly audit your system for unauthorized access, privileged access, fraudulat behaviour and other signs of exploitation with SAP Enterprise Threat Detection.

For further information and the latest updates, refer to the SAP Security Note 3627998.

SAP Enterprise Threat Detection information: sap.com

Kind regards,

Arndt

Stay vigilant and ensure your SAP systems are protected from evolving threats.

entry.title: Re: Print Setup not displaying when click on print icon
entry.content:
A few requirements to print....

First, your load balancer must use Sticky Sessions so the report stay in session on the Server that gets the request, I assume it's been configured since you don't have other issues.

Second, a real printer must be installed on all BOE Servers, CR requires this, if the Service can't find a real printer then the PDF export is the only option.

Third, BOE Admin must give the users permission to print on all server.

Since you are using BOE you should have a support contract, go here: https://support.sap.com/en/index.html

And create an Incident and have a SAP Support Engineer help you to configure your servers.

entry.title: Re: How to combine two vendor's business volume and split...
entry.content:
Hi @Nx ,

For customer rebates I can confirm that this is possible. I assume that the same approach works for supplier rebates too.

  • Set up a condition contract which includes the business volume for all relevant suppliers.
  • In customizing add the supplier as header split criteria to the split criteria.

During the settlement of the condition contracts this will create multiple settlement documents. One for each supplier. 

If the scale base of the settlement conditions shall use the total business volume of all suppliers then some further customizing is required. An additional condition type for the total value is required. For customer rebates SAP delivers condition type REBT. Within 2535889 - CCM - Description of delivered configuration - SAP for Me you find the following documentation:

"Explanation REBT: This condition type - yet not used in the delivered pricing procedures – is
designated to adopt the total business volume of a settlement run in case that several settlement
documents are created due to header split criteria as in case of the multiple customer scenario. You
can include this condition type in your pricing procedures, combined with a suitable configuration, to
use the total business volume to determine the corresponding scale level for sales rebated. In the
pricing procedure you must mark the corresponding step with subtotal 5, and you use scale routine
002 CCS Total BusVolume for the sales rebate condition type."

The condition for the total has to be added to the pricing procedure and to the customizing of the amount fields in the "Profile for Business Volume Determination".
